entry.title: Re: Error in BAPI_CONDITION_CONTRACT_CHANGE No data is ch...
entry.content:
It seems, you have not set the change indicator flag correctly. For any field you want to change, you must fill the value in CONDITIONITEMDATAIN, Set the corresponding field in CONDITIONITEMDATAINX to 'X' or the correct change indicator. Also set UPDATEFLAG = 'U' in CONDITIONITEMDATAINX for that condition line. If you don’t set the X flags, the BAPI ignores the field even if you pass a new value.

From buffering issue point of view, if you check WCOCO immediately after the BAPI in the same LUW/session, you might still see buffered old data. Exit and re‑enter the transaction to confirm.

entry.title: CREATING CAPM APPLICATION WITH NODE.JS BY USING S/4 HANA DATABASE
entry.content:
Hello All,

In this Blog I would like to share some knowledge on how to Create a basic CAPM application using Sap Business Application Studio and we are going to use the SAP S/4 Hana system to connect and fetch the data.

Lets Divide this Blog into three sections:

1. Prerequisites

2.  Connecting with S/4 HANA Data Base.

3.CRUD Operations

In this Blog lets see what are all the subscriptions and settings to be done to start our application.

Let.. Set.. Go!!

NOTE: May Be This Blog Seems To Be Lengthy, Still Give It A Try U Will Surely Love IT 😀

 

 

 

Step1: Lets Subscribe to SAP HANA CLOUD:

Open your SAP BTP trial account and navigate to Service Market Place. Search for S/4 Hana Cloud

 

After Selecting HANA Cloud, you will get the screen like below and Please click on Create.  

 

 

 

Click on Tools and then Create.

 

Once you click on View Subscription , here it shows as below image

 

Note: Remember after subscribing any service you should add security because every service will have its own Role Collections.

Now lets navigate to Users and Click on Default Identity Provider.

 

 

Click on Assign Role Collections, there you can find roles related to Hana cloud( You will find all the roles for the services that are subscribed).

 

 

Select them and click and assign.

 

You can find them under your role collections. Now you have your HANA DB. Lets open it.

 

Step2: Open SAP HANA Cloud and Lets Create Instance.

 

Click on Create Instance and then select HANA Cloud DB.

 

 

 

Here its asking us from which environment our service is going to run, So we need to sign in to Cloud Foundry with your Default Identity Provider Credentials( your email id).Then it returns you this Message.

 

 

 

 

 

Select your space which is default given as dev ( I renamed its as Dev). Instance name can be anything of your choice.

 

 

Enter any password of your choice.

Now leave the next step as it is with storage of 16gb and next please select allow all IP addresses so that it will not block any.

 

 

Click on the three dots over there and there you will find an option to Start. In 10 to 15min your instance would be running.

 

 

Step 3: Setup Work Zone(Fiori Launch Pad):

Search in Market Place > Work Zone

 

Click Create 

 

Please select the Plan as Subscriptions > standard. 

 

Our Subscription would be in progress.

 

 

Note: If this error exists, please subscribe to your Cloud Identity Services.

If you get this, please add trust configuration. So follow the steps below

Initially follow the same process of Subscribing Cloud Identity Provider User Role Collections

Fix: Configure OIDC Trust in SAP BTP

  1. Log in to SAP BTP Cockpit
    Go to your subaccount where you want to subscribe to the application.
  2. Go to Security → Trust Configuration
    This is where you manage identity provider (IdP) trust settings.
  3. Add SAP Cloud Identity Services as an OIDC IdP
    • Click Establish Trust.
    • Choose SAP Cloud Identity Services.
    • Select OpenID Connect (not SAML).
    • Enter the required details (Issuer URL, Client ID, etc.) — if you have Identity Authentication service (IAS) set up, you can copy these from there.
  4. Set as Default for Business Users

                   Make sure the new OIDC IdP is assigned to business users in your subaccount.

  1. Save & Retry Subscription
    Go back to the subscription page and try again.

Assign the Role collections to users what are all available. Check them all and Click on Assign.

Step 4: CREATE A HANA DB INSTANCE:

Navigate to Service Market Place > Select HANA DB > Create > Under Plan select the Instance.

 

Step 5: Subscribe to Business Application Studio.

Note: By default SAP Business Application Studio would be subscribed. If not subscribe it by yourself.

 

Are you all done!! Lets get into next Episode soon...

References:

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/

https://help.sap.com/fiori_bs2013/helpdata/en/a7/1564526ba1f25fe10000000a423f68/content.htm?no_cache...

Hope it’s helpful 😉

 

Thanks,
Divya MANDAVA.

entry.title: Re: Accelerate the depreciation of one asset
entry.content:
Hello @Dylan2 

Thank you for reaching out to the SAP Community. Your question and the shared screenshot are very helpful

What you have done with transaction type 640 – Unplanned Depreciation on prior-year acquisitions is technically correct, but it explains why you don’t see the 500 CNY as accelerated depreciation under ledger 0L in Manage Fixed Assets.

Why:

Transaction type 640 is used for impairments or extraordinary write-downs. It generates an FI posting and appears in the Transactions / Asset History Sheet view, but it does not modify planned depreciation.

Only the values calculated from the depreciation key and useful life are considered by the depreciation engine. Manual postings made with 640 are not included in the depreciation forecast.

If the goal is to accelerate future depreciation:

Use the Change Asset Master Data app.

Reduce the useful life or alter the depreciation key in the Time-Dependent Data section.

Once the system has recalculated the planned depreciation, you’ll see the changes reflected under ledger 0L in Manage Fixed Assets.

When should you use 640?

Only for true unplanned depreciation events such as impairments, damage, or extraordinary value reductions

SAP Help Portal – Depreciation Posting Run

Post Depreciation Manually - Unplanned and Planned

SAP Help Portal – Change Asset Master Data

In brief, the method you used posts correctly, but it doesn’t speed up planned depreciation. To do that, you need to update the master data (useful life or key) so that the system recalculates depreciation in future runs.

Feel free to reach out again if you still need further support

Thanks again, and kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Regarding the method for calculating the fiscal year...
entry.content:
As rightly pointed out, your requirement is not clear. Please answer the following:

  • Why do you need to display the fiscal year — is it for reporting context, filtering, or calculations?
  • Should the fiscal year be based on the current system date only, or on a user‑selected date?
  • Is the fiscal year definition the same for all company codes, or does it vary?
  • Do you already have a fiscal calendar table in the model, or do we need to derive it dynamically?
  • Should the fiscal year be derived from the posting date, document date, or purely the system date?
  • How should the company code influence the fiscal year calculation — do different company codes have different fiscal year variants?
  • Do you have a mapping of company code → fiscal year variant available in the data model?

entry.title: Re: Data Replication Framework - BusinessPartner Replicat...
entry.content:
Hello @StevenKr 

Thank you for the question.

Note that when you try to replicate BP master data to SAP EWM using the SAP_COM_0008 communication scenario in SAP Public Cloud, the general BP Role is always required. Without it, EWM cannot interpret the Customer or the supplier roles. These depend on the General role as a foundation to that process.

If EWM receives either Customer or Supplier role but not the General role, the replication will fail with the error as it does in your scenario.

I recommend you evaluate the following checks:

  • Confirm that the BP indeed has the 000000-General BP Role assigned.  KBA 3059674 Which is required by EWM to be sent along with the Customer/Supplier roles.
  • Check the replication model setup and ensure the Define Business Partner configuration does not have any role exclusion.
  • You mentioned that your EWM colleague sees only FLCU01/FLVN0, that means the general role was not transmitted or processed. Review the payload sent via the SOAP service using the Message Dashboard to verify the General Role 000000 is included. If this is present and it still does not arrive in EWM, then issue is on the EWM configuration.
  • You should ensure that you create all BPs with General Role. Thereafter re-run replications for all affected BPs.

If after taking those steps the issue still persists then raise an incident under LO-MD-BP which represents the Business Partner and make a reference to SAP_COM_0008 scenario.

Consult the following for more details.

KBA 3245240 Filters for Business Partner (SAP_COM_0008) SOAP Replication Not Taking Effect

KBA 3329385

KBA 3059674

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Which technologies are used to develop travel apps?
entry.content:
Great question! Travel apps require a mix of frontend, backend, mobile frameworks, APIs, and cloud technologies to deliver smooth, scalable, and feature-rich experiences for users. Here’s a breakdown of the main technologies used to develop travel apps:

1. Frontend Development (User Interface)

This is what users see and interact with:

  • Mobile Frameworks:

    • Swift / Objective-C → iOS native apps

    • Java / Kotlin → Android native apps

    • Flutter (Dart) → Cross-platform (single codebase for iOS & Android)

    • React Native (JavaScript) → Cross-platform development

  • UI Libraries & Tools: Material UI (Android), SwiftUI (iOS), Shadcn/UI, Tailwind CSS

2. Backend Development (Server-Side & Logic)

Handles data processing, booking logic, and secure transactions:

  • Programming Languages:

    • Python (Django, Flask, FastAPI)

    • Node.js (Express.js, NestJS)

    • Java (Spring Boot)

    • PHP (Laravel, Symfony)

    • Ruby on Rails

  • Databases:

    • Relational: PostgreSQL, MySQL

    • NoSQL: MongoDB, Firebase Realtime DB

3. APIs & Integrations (Core for Travel Apps)

Travel apps rely heavily on third-party integrations:

  • Flight & Hotel APIs: Amadeus, Skyscanner, Expedia, Booking.com, Sabre, Travelport

  • Maps & Location: Google Maps, Mapbox, OpenStreetMap

  • Weather APIs: OpenWeatherMap, Weatherstack

  • Payment Gateways: Stripe, PayPal, Razorpay, Braintree

  • Chat & Support: Twilio, Sendbird, Firebase Messaging

4. Cloud & Hosting Services

For scalability and performance:

  • AWS (Amazon Web Services) → EC2, S3, RDS, Lambda

  • Google Cloud Platform (GCP) → Firebase, BigQuery

  • Microsoft Azure → App Services, SQL Database

  • Heroku / DigitalOcean for startups & MVPs

5. Security & Compliance

Since travel apps handle payments and personal data:

  • Authentication: OAuth 2.0, JWT, Firebase Auth

  • Encryption: SSL/TLS, AES-256

  • Compliance: GDPR (Europe), PCI DSS (Payments), CCPA (California)

6. AI & Smart Features

For personalization and user experience:

  • Chatbots / Virtual Assistants → Dialogflow, IBM Watson, Rasa

  • AI Recommendations → TensorFlow, PyTorch, ML Kit

  • Language Translation → Google Translate API, Microsoft Translator

7. Other Essential Tools

  • Analytics: Google Analytics, Firebase Analytics, Mixpanel

  • Push Notifications: Firebase Cloud Messaging, OneSignal

  • Testing: Appium, Selenium, XCTest, JUnit

  • CI/CD: GitHub Actions, Jenkins, Bitrise

✅ In short:

  • Native apps → Swift (iOS), Kotlin (Android)

  • Cross-platform apps → Flutter, React Native

  • Backend → Node.js, Python, or Java

  • Cloud → AWS, GCP, Azure

  • APIs → Travel booking, payment, maps, weather integrations

entry.title: TDS provisioning
entry.content:
Hello SAP community,

We are currently facing an issue while executing the end-to-end process for maintaining TDS provisions on service accruals through to final payment

To illustrate the scenario, let's assume that we posted an accrual of ₹60000 based on the annual services agreed for a particular service. The WHT tax type we're using is 194J @ 10% which is already maintained in the supplier master data. We also ensured to use invoice based WHT tax types/codes in this case.

  1.  Given the above scenario, we issue a SES at year end amounting to ₹60000
  2.  Now we enter the TDS provision in the app: 'Enter provisions - India' with reference to the purchasing document we created.  JE generated will be: -
    TDS provision A/C..Dr.6000 
    To Withholding tax A/C 6000
  3.  Moving on the next financial year, we post the supplier invoice against the purchasing document that we created earlier.
    GR/IR A/C..Dr60000 
    To Vendor A/C 54000
    To Withholding tax A/C 6000
  4.  Now we utilize the March provision that we posted earlier via the application: 'Utilize provisions-India' 
    Withholding Tax A/C…Dr.6001 
    To TDS provision A/C 6001
  5. We then proceed to reverse the provision that we created via the app: Utilize provision documents - India. 
    TDS provision A/C-6000 
    Withholding Tax A/C…Dr. -6000
  6.  We finally proceed to make the TDS payment in the app: ‘Create remittance challan’, thus completing the process. 

However, we're unable to issue the remittance challan due to the following issue: -

Also, we’re unsure about the extra ₹1 showing up in Step 4 — how did the amount become ₹6001 instead of ₹6000?

Any guidance or clarification regarding these would be greatly appreciated.

  • The discrepancy in the ₹1 difference

  • The remittance challan issue.

Thank you.

Best regards,

Rishav.

entry.title: Re: How to connect from SAP Public cloud(Odata) to SAP ME...
entry.content:
Hello @Sah1 

Thank you for your question.

Yes, you can connect the Public Cloud via OData APIs to an external MES system such as the ones (which can include a third-party solution) you mentioned in your question. However, there are some differences if you compare that to the classic on-prem RFC/JCO connections.

Please note that in SAP Public Cloud, direct RFC calls are not supported. Instead, all integration must go through the public APIs which are available in the SAP API Business Hub.

To answer your question on integration options for MES, make sure you use OData APIs from the S/4HANA cloud. Third Party MES Integration With SAP S4HANA Cloud, SAP Digital Manufacturing Integration Guide Connect your MES systems either through:

  • HTTPs calls to the S/4HANA Cloud OData endpoints or
  • Through SAP CPI as a middleware, which is the recommended approach to handle authentication, mappings and error handling.

Please note that you must create a Communication User + Communication Arrangement for the required OData API. Third Party MES Integration With SAP S4HANA Cloud

To consume MES, configure REST/OData clinets. SAP MII as an example can call OData endpoints directly via HTTP adapter and not through JCO.

Consult the references below for more details.

Integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

Third Party MES Integration With SAP S4HANA Cloud

Integrating Plant Data from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition to SAP Integrated Business Planning

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: S4 tables for Invoice Lifecycle Report?
entry.content:
The OBJECTID in CDHDR/CDPOS is for the change‑document object like BKPF for FI header, RBKP for MM invoice header. So unless the field you’re looking for is part of that object’s change‑doc definition, it won’t be logged there.

Depending on whether you are using standard S/4HANA AP workflow or OpenText VIM, the relevant tables differ:

Below are the Standard S/4HANA Invoice Workflow

  • SWWWIHEAD – Workflow item header (task, work item ID, current agent)
  • SWWUSERWI – Work item → user assignment
  • SWWLOGHIST – Workflow log history (status changes)
  • SWW_CONT / SWW_CONTOB – Container elements (process type, document refs)

Similarly, for MM/FI header, you can consider, RBKP which will link to workflow via object key and BKPF.

Now in order to join to your document ID, start from your invoice number in RBKP (for MM) or BKPF (for FI). Get the workflow instance ID from the linkage table (SWWORGTASK or via event linkage in SWEINST). Join to SWWWIHEAD / SWWUSERWI to get the current agent. Join to SWWLOGHIST to get the history rows you see in the Life Cycle report.

entry.title: Re: Business Partner replication to EWM – General Role (0...
entry.content:
Depending on your EWM release, the enhancement spot you’re looking for is usually one of:

  • BUPA_INBOUND_BADI – BAdI: Inbound Processing of Business Partner
  • BUPA_GENERAL_UPDATE – BAdI: Change/Enhance BP Data Before Save
  • MDG_BS_BP_INBOUND – BAdI: Inbound Processing for BP Replication (used in DRF inbound)

In some decentral EWM systems, the wrapper BAdI is called /SCWM/EX_BP_RCV or /SCWM/EX_BP_RCV_MERGE, depending on whether you’re using IDoc or web service replication.

entry.title: API & Excipient Calculation in Process Order by MQC
entry.content:
Hi SAP Folks,

Need your help in the following client requirement.

Requirement: 

Client is manufacturing 5 lakh Nos. tablets:

1. Components are API & Excipient.

2. Both the components are stock-up in batches.

3. API component is having Assay & LOD characteristics.

4. Quantity of API is calculated using the following formula,

    = (400 X 100 X 100)/((100 - LOD) X Assay)

& Quantity of Excipient is calculated using the following formula,

   = 205 - Quantity of API

5. Every Batch of API will have different Assay and LOD values (LOD = 0 - 0.5%, Assay = 98 - 100%)

Example - 

Batch A --> LOD = 0.3% & Assay = 99.60%

Quantity of API = (400 X 100 X 100)/((100 - 0.3) X 99.60) = 402.815 mg/tab

Quantity of API required for manufacturing 5 L tabs = (402.815 X 5 L)/(1000 X 1000) = 201.407 kg

But already there is a batch, Batch E of 180 kg quantity.

So, how many tablets could be produced using Batch E = 180 kg quantity of API,

= (180 X 1000 X 1000)/(402.815) = 4,46,855 Nos of tablets

No. of tablets to be produce from Batch B = 500000 - 446855 = 53,145 Nos.

Batch B --> Assay = 99.90% & LOD = 0.5%

Quantity of API = (400 X 100 X 100)/((100 - 0.5) X 99.90) = 402.412 mg/tab

Qty. required for 53,145 tabs = (53145 X 402.412)/(1000 X 1000) = 21.386 kg

Actual Qty of API - 180 + 21.386 =  201.386 kg

Excipient qty = 205 - 201.386 = 3.614 kg

 

Thanks & Regards 

#Material Quantity Calculation  SAP Industry Process Framework SAP Help Portal SAP Community SAP S/4HANA SAP ERP

entry.title: Innovating with SAP C4C: Dynamic MDRO to Handle Massive Ticket Updates
entry.content:
Disclaimer:

  • This blog does not cover the basics of creating an MDRO.
  • The business logic described here is for illustration purposes only and cannot include actual production details due to organizational policies.

Introduction

In SAP Cloud for Customer (C4C), Mass Data Run Objects (MDROs) are commonly used to execute bulk updates in the background. They act like scheduled jobs where you define selection filters, write custom code, and let the system process records in batches.

But when working with millions of records in SAP Service Cloud, standard MDROs quickly run into performance bottlenecks — primarily the 10-hour runtime limit.

In this blog, I’ll explain how we solved this limitation by designing an innovative Dynamic MDRO framework that can handle tens of millions of tickets seamlessly.

Use Case

Product: SAP Cloud for Customer (C4C)
Objective: Update Service Tickets using MDRO
Scenario: A new Quarter field was introduced on tickets, and we needed to populate it based on ticket creation month:

Month Quarter
Jan – MarQ1
Apr – JunQ2
Jul – SepQ3
Oct – DecQ4

(Actual business logic was more complex and involved massive datasets. This is a simplified illustration.)

The Challenge with Standard MDRO

When we tried updating ~40 million tickets using a single MDRO, we hit a critical issue:

SAP C4C MDROs fail when a package execution exceeds 10 hours.

SAP’s Recommendation:

  • Reduce the selection data volume

  • Break the updates into multiple scheduled runs

Our Constraint:
We couldn’t reduce the dataset — every ticket needed to be updated in one logical flow.

Our Solution: Dynamic MDRO (Nested MDRO Approach)

To overcome these limitations, we designed a Dynamic MDRO framework:

  1. Parent MDRO → Fetches eligible records in configurable intervals (e.g., creation dates).

  2. Data Chunking → Splits large datasets into smaller batches automatically.

  3. Child MDROs → For each batch, a new child MDRO is created dynamically and executed.

  4. Parameterization → Batch size is configurable (default 500 records per MDRO).

How It Works

  • Step 1: Parent MDRO identifies the full dataset.

  • Step 2: It divides the dataset into smaller logical packages.

  • Step 3: It triggers multiple child MDROs dynamically, each handling a small subset.

  • Step 4: Since each MDRO deals with fewer records, execution time stays well below the 10-hour limit.

Key Features

  • ⚡Parameterized Batching → Fully configurable batch size

  • 🤖Automated Execution → No manual intervention needed

  • 📈High Scalability → Works seamlessly with tens of millions of records

  • ✅Timeout-Free → Each MDRO stays well within SAP limits

🚀Groundbreaking Performance Improvement 

Before implementing Dynamic MDRO, we were stuck with:

  • ~7,000 tickets processed in 10 hours using standard MDRO

  • At this pace, updating 40M+ tickets would have taken months or even years

After implementing Dynamic MDRO:

  • We updated millions of tickets in just ~20 minutes 

  • Achieved end-to-end automation without manual intervention

  • Delivered one of the fastest, most optimized solutions in our SAP Service Cloud landscape

This was a game-changing result that completely redefined how we handle mass updates in SAP C4C.

Benefits Achieved

Aspect Standard MDRO Dynamic MDRO (Our Approach)
Data VolumeLimitedUnlimited
Timeout Handling10-hour riskEliminated
AutomationPartialFully automated
PerformanceSlower with large dataHighly optimized

Groundbreaking Performance Improvement 🚀

Before implementing Dynamic MDRO, we were stuck with:

  • ~7,000 tickets processed in 10 hours using standard MDRO

  • At this pace, updating 40M+ tickets would have taken months or even years

After implementing Dynamic MDRO:

  • We updated millions of tickets in just ~20 minutes 

  • Achieved end-to-end automation without manual intervention

  • Delivered one of the fastest, most optimized solutions in our SAP Service Cloud landscape

This was a game-changing result that completely redefined how we handle mass updates in SAP C4C.

Conclusion

By designing a Dynamic MDRO in SAP C4C, we:

  • Solved the 10-hour runtime limitation

  • Automated mass updates for ~40M tickets

  • Built a scalable, reusable framework

This approach can be applied wherever standard MDROs fail due to data volume constraints.

Final Note

⚠️Disclaimer: The logic used here is for illustration only and cannot reflect the actual production logic due to confidentiality.


Next Blog Preview

In my next blog, I’ll cover:

  • How to create child MDRO from Parent MDRO

  • Technical details from SDK

entry.title: Re: TDS provisioning
entry.content:
In your original provision (Enter provisions – India), the system calculated exactly ₹6 000 (10% of ₹60 000) based on the SES amount and the WHT code. When you later post the supplier invoice, the WHT engine recalculates the tax amount from the invoice line(s). If there’s any difference in base amount (e.g. due to currency conversion, unit price rounding, or inclusion/exclusion of freight/other conditions), the calculated WHT can differ by a few paise.

For information, the Utilise provisions – India app doesn’t just “pick up” the original ₹6 000 — it matches the open WHT line items from the invoice to the provision and posts the utilisation for the actual open amount. If the invoice WHT line is ₹6 000.50, the posting will round to ₹6 001 in the G/L. This is why you see Withholding Tax A/C Dr 6 001 / To TDS Provision A/C 6 001.

In order to confirm this, display the FI document for the supplier invoice (FB03) and check the exact WHT line item amount in document currency and local currency. You’ll likely see it’s not exactly ₹6 000.00.

Now coming to "Not Assigned" issue, in the Post with Clearing screen of the Create Remittance Challan app, the “Assigned” total must match the sum of the open WHT items you want to remit. In your case, you have two open items on the WHT account:

  • ₹6 001 from the invoice (payment‑time WHT)
  • ₹6 001 from the provision utilisation

If you only select one of them, the other remains “Not assigned”, and the “Not assigned” column will show the combined total of the unassigned items (₹12 002 if both are unassigned). The challan process expects you to select all relevant open WHT items for that section code/TAN and assign them to the payment line.

In order to fix this, in the selection screen, make sure you filter by the correct section code and TAN so both items appear. In the line item list, select both ₹6 001 items and assign them to the bank clearing line. The “Not assigned” amount should drop to zero before you post.

entry.title: Re: TDS provisioning
entry.content:
Hello @Rishav4 

Your detailed scenario is correct for e2e TDS provision handling in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud focusing on India localisation.

Looking at the first issue in step 4 about 6001 instead of 6000, this is a rounding difference. The reason is

  • in Public Cloud, withholding tax calculation is always aligned with invoice-base WHT determination and your system currency setting.
  • Decimals are rounded differently, especially when tax base or percentages are calculated across multiple line items during provision creation and further utilisation. That explains why the system rounded the extra ₹1.

The second issue you mentioned about the error you experience in Remittance Challan usually occurs for some reasons.

  1. Your provision document is already utilised and reserved but the corresponding tax payable balance is not available in the WHT account.
  2. There is a mismatch in the challan grouping due to the extra rounding.
  3. The challan app requires the correct balance in the WHT payable account to match the provisioned amounts.

I recommend you check:

First, in the App “Display Line Items in General Ledger” to ensure that the WHT payable account has the correct balance (6000 vs. 6001)

Then, in the Manage Journal Entries Fiori app, trace the provision and check if the extra rounding line is sitting unallocated.

Finally, if you find a mismatch, run the Utilize Provisions-India” again or post a small manual adjustment journal entry to align the balances before you generate the challan.

If the mismatch persists, consider opening an SAP incident under component FI-LOC-FI-IN

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: How to trigger Revenue Recognition in S/4HANA Public...
entry.content:
A Preliminary Billing Document is nothing but Proforma in SD and it does not post to FI/CO. Also, it is not considered a revenue‑recognition event in the standard integration content. Therefore, it will not generate RAIs in the Revenue Accounting engine.

Instead of a pro forma, issue an interim actual billing document (posting to FI) at the milestone where you want recognition. Configure your pricing so that this interim bill has zero net effect on customer receivables if needed (e.g., offsetting lines), but still posts revenue for EBRR to pick up. This will create RAIs and trigger recognition.

For some reasons, if the business requirement is “recognise revenue at preliminary bill stage” and you must stay in Public Cloud standard, then, re‑design the process so that the preliminary bill is replaced by an actual milestone bill that posts to FI (even if it’s later netted off). Or, if you’re in a professional services scenario, leverage event‑based recognition from project events instead of from the billing doc.

entry.title: Re: How to trigger Revenue Recognition in S/4HANA Public...
entry.content:
Hello @LDB 

There is a clash between your requirement and what is possible in the Public Cloud. Please note the following:

  • Revenue Accounting Items are only created from final billing documents that are marked as revenue relevant. Which means, preliminary Billing Document (Proforma invoices) are not revenue relevant and therefore cannot trigger RAIs or revenue recognition postings.
  • The restriction is standard in Public Cloud because RAI are generated only at the stage of final customer invoice. Preliminary billing documents are only for simulation and review purposes.

However, there are options you can consider in Public Cloud. These include:

  1. The usage of Contract-based Revenue Recognition. You can configure for example service contract with periodic revenue recognition. Doing that will ensure your revenue recognition can occur independently of billing and based on your contract’s fulfilment rules.
  2. Another is the Down Payments/Partial invoices (Milestones Billing). This comes in play if your business process requires revenue to be recognise progressively. You can use it to carry out periodic billing with final invoices for each milestone. Each final billing document will then create RAIs.
  3. Finally, if your business requires simulation-level RAIs at the primary stage, consider Custom Extension using BTP (side-by-side extension). This enables you capture preliminary billing events and provides a reporting layer. Please note that this is a workaround and not a standard Revenue Account.

Consult the following references for details

Revenue Accounting Overview

SAP Billing and Revenue Innovation Management Localization: Innovations in 2502

Event Based Revenue Recognition - Provider Contract (Subscription Billing) - (5DQ)

Billing and Revenue Integration in SAP S/4HANA Cloud

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: After executing the data action, the manually entered parameter values remain cached for the session
entry.content:
Hi,

We’re working with a scenario where a data action prompt is prefilled based on table selection. The input controls are dynamically assigned via script according to the selected table row. This setup works well—as long as the user doesn’t manually change the prompt values.

However, once a user manually modifies the parameter values in the data action prompt (f.e. different cost center) and executes the action, those manually entered values persist for the session. After that, the prompt no longer reflects updates from the input controls, even though the script continues assigning the correct values.

While resetting the story via Edit > Reset resolves the issue, it’s not a viable option due to long loading times.

Could you please confirm if this is a known behavior? And is there any recommended workaround—ideally one that doesn’t require rebuilding the prompt dialog from scratch?

Many thanks,
Fabian

entry.title: Date Constraints in SAP Project and Resource Management
entry.content:
Meet Deadlines - Date Constraints in SAP Project and Resource Management 
SAP Project and Resource Management (SAP PRM) now allows you to define date constraints to ensure that critical project plan elements (work packages or milestones) start and finish on time. This reduces the likelihood of delays, facilitates the anticipation of bottlenecks, and enhances project scheduling capabilities. 
You can set 'Must Start On' and 'Must Finish On' constraints using the 'Manage Project Plans' app. In the Gantt Chart, constraints are displayed as small red triangles positioned on the top for Start Constraints and on the bottom for Finish Constraints. Milestones are limited to a Planned Finish date, which means they include the finish constraint but do not have a start constraint. 
When constraints are set and scheduling is initiated, any resulting conflicts—such as overlapping project plan elements—are shown as messages for the affected project plan elements, supporting easier access and quicker resolution.  
There are various methods to set or remove constraints, each tailored to specific purposes: 
 
There are various methods to set or remove constraints, each tailored to specific purposes: 
1. Detail Page 
2. Action Button 
3. Gantt Chart 
4. Table View 
5. Project Plan Service API 
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

1. Detail Page – Specify Constraints and include a corresponding Note (Reason) while maintaining a comprehensive overview of the selected project plan element:
 

2. Action Button - for setting or removing constraints on multiple project elements: 
Select the project elements you want to modify, then click the 'Action' Button to either add or remove constraints. If you opt for ‘Set Date Constraints’ on a work package, you'll automatically set the Planned Start and Planned Finish as 'Must Start On' and 'Must Finish On' constraints. For milestones, only the Planned Finish date will be set as the 'Must Finish On' constraint. 

3. Right-Click Menu on Gantt Chart – Provides enhanced individual control and quick access for adjustments within the Gantt view: 
Right-click on the relevant bar and select 'Set Date Constraints' or 'Remove Date Constraints' to choose whether to apply or remove the 'Must Start On' or 'Must Finish On' constraint. 
 

4. Table view – quick date entry by tabbing through constraint fields: 
Utilize the table settings to reveal the columns: ‘Start Date Constraint’ and ‘Finish Date Constraint’. Switching to the ‘Display Table’ view provides a clearer overview of the project plan in table format. 

5. Project Plan Service API - to modify constraint settings:  
For detailed information, refer to the Business Accelerator Hub.

entry.title: Compilation of ABAP SQL window functions from the ABAP Keyword Documentation
entry.content:
If like me you don't know well the ABAP SQL window functions (partitions with OVER, window functions) and have difficulties to quickly choose between them, here's a compilation of the ABAP Keyword Documentation + ABAP results. It concerns ABAP 7.58.

  • AVG (ask me if you need it)
  • CORR (ask)
  • CORR_SPEARMAN (ask)
  • COUNT
  • DENSE_RANK
  • FIRST_VALUE
  • LAG
  • LAST_VALUE
  • LEAD
  • MAX
  • MEDIAN (ask)
  • MIN
  • NTILE
  • RANK
  • ROW_NUMBER
  • STDDEV (ask)
  • VAR (ask)

FIRST_VALUE, LAST_VALUE

Content of table DEMO_UPDATE:

IDCOL1COL2COL3
A1562
B1462
C1862
D11062
E197862
F192788
G1099
H10124
I2100144
J24344
K2444
L21744
M23344
N210044
O210144
P2583955
Q254877
R218133
S355434623
T31001111

ABAP SQL:

SELECT 
      id, 
      col1, 
      col2, 
      col3, 
      FIRST_VALUE( col2 ) OVER( PARTITION BY col1 ORDER BY col3 ) 
                  AS first_value, 
      LAST_VALUE( col2 ) OVER( PARTITION BY col1 ORDER BY col3 ) 
                  AS last_value, 
      LAST_VALUE( col2 ) OVER( PARTITION BY col1 ORDER BY col3 
                  ROWS BETWEEN UNBOUNDED PRECEDING 
                  AND UNBOUNDED FOLLOWING ) 
                  AS last_value_correct 
      FROM demo_update 
      INTO TABLE @FINAL(result).

Result and explanations (copied from ABAP Keyword Documentation):

 

The class CL_DEMO_SELECT_FIRST_LAST divides the rows from the DEMO_UPDATE table into three partitions (orange, red, purple), depending on their value in COL1. Within the partitions, the rows are ordered by their value in COL3.

The column FIRST_VALUE returns the first value of COL2 for each partition.

The column LAST_VALUE does not return the last value. With the LAST_VALUE function, framing is an important aspect to consider. The default frame is ROWS BETWEEN UNBOUNDED PRECEDING AND CURRENT ROW, so the LAST_VALUE function always returns the value from the current row. To find the last value for a partition or a window, the correct frame has to be specified explicitly: ROWS BETWEEN UNBOUNDED PRECEDING AND UNBOUNDED FOLLOWING as shown in LAST_VALUE_CORRECT. If COL3 contains duplicate values, the rows are considered equal and the last value from the group of equals is returned.

In this example, COL3 has multiple duplicate values. The key field - here the field ID - is used to sort rows with the same value.

entry.title: error with webservice Procedure in SQL Anywhere
entry.content:
I have a problem while calling an externail API from inside Procedure in SQL-Anywhere database.

The exact error code is:

Could not execute statement.
The secure connection to the remote host failed: The connection was
closed from the other side
SQLCODE=-990, ODBC 3 State="HY000"
Line 1, column 1)

My Code looks like this:

create or replace procedure myprocget()
url 'https://mydomain/api/'
type 'http:get'
header 'Authorization: Bearer ****'
set 'HTTP(VERSION=1.1)';
call myprocget()-- OK

create or replace procedure myprocpost(mybody long varchar)
url 'https://mydomain/api/'
type 'http:post:application/json'
header 'Content-Type: application/json\nAuthorization: Bearer ****'
set 'HTTP(VERSION=1.1)';
call myprocpost('{"customer_code": 1}')--I get the above error

Despite the above error, everything works on the webserver, and the post (with {"customer_code": 1} is done on the webserver) but I see only the error in my database.

I have looked in the Forum for a similar error, I find only those related to certificate, which is not the problem in my case since the GET method to the same URL and endpoint works fine.

The only thing is that the POST Method on this endpoint delivers HTTP 402 (No Content)!
I dont even think that this could be the problem, since calling the endpoint with Curl also works:

curl "https://mydomain/api/" --header "Content-Type: application/json" --header "Authorization: Bearer ****" --data "{\"customer_code\": 1}"


Does someone have any idea?

entry.title: Re: There is already a handling unit * posted for GR with...
entry.content:
In your case, the HU number already exists in ECC from 2015, so when decentralized EWM tries to post the goods issue back to ERP, the inbound qRFC fails because ERP sees that HU as already “consumed” in a historical delivery. That’s why EWM shows the delivery as completed (because the warehouse task/HU processing finished locally). The outbound queue to ERP is stuck, so ERP’s goods movement status never flips to “Completed”.

  • To fix this, go to SMQ1 in EWM, filter by your delivery number or LUW containing /SCWM/… function modules (e.g. /SCWM/ERP_GOODSMVT_OUTBOUND). Display the error text. You should see something like “HU already exists” or “HU already assigned to delivery …”.
  • Go to HUMO in ECC, Enter the HU number and check the Status, Assigned document (old delivery from 2015). This confirms the HU number conflict.

So with the above scenario, you have two options.

Option A – Change HU number in EWM
Unpack the item from the problematic HU in EWM.  Create a new HU with a fresh number range (one that does not exist in ERP). Repack the goods and re‑post the goods issue.  This avoids the conflict entirely.

Option B – Clean up HU in ERP
If the old HU is no longer relevant and can be archived/closed, you could technically delete or renumber it in ERP — but in practice, HU numbers are not meant to be reused, so this is rarely recommended in production.

SAP best practice is to ensure separate HU number ranges for EWM and ERP to avoid reuse.

Once the HU conflict is resolved:

Go back to SMQ1 in EWM, select the stuck LUW and choose Execute LUW (or Activate if it’s in SMQ2 inbound in ERP). The goods movement should post in ERP, and the delivery status will update.

entry.title: Re: Self Service Procure cookbook doesn't describe how th...
entry.content:
Hello @Robson1 

Thank you for reaching out to the SAP Community.

In F1639A – Create Purchase Requisition (Advanced), the Employee Catalogue only shows if:

It is created and active in Configure Catalogues SSCUI as Employee Catalogue.

The user has the role SAP_BR_EMPLOYEE_PROCUREMENT, which includes catalogue access

User defaults for Purchasing Group/Plant are maintained.

If these are in place, the Employee Catalogue will appear alongside the internal catalogue in the search.

Best regards,
Chuma
